ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt that I became a significantly stronger Latin reader. My reading is now much clearer and I am more confident in it. I also feel that I have direction on what strengths to build upon in preparation for future Latin learning.
I learned how to effectively apply and build upon the first semester of LATN 110. My knowledge of Latin Grammar was "completed" and we began regularly translating latin passages.
I developed reading competence in basic classical Latin, with an understanding of Latin vocabulary and grammar.
Built on L1 Latin; how to read prose, poetry in Latin; the basics of meter; some Roman history
A strong grasp of the Latin Language as well as some knowledge of Roman history

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No weaknesses come to mind with this course. The instructor was exceptionally kind and generous in leading our reading and prodding us towards accurate translations, and the comradery of my classmates was admirable. The readings were engaging and managed to give us a nuanced background in salient issues of Roman history (especially sexuality/gender, class dynamics, enslavement) while also challenging us grammatically. Language learning can often feel like a form of academic hazing, but this class was by contrast extremely warm, welcoming and rigorous; I felt that each student was being met where they were as a learner and their needs accommodated for. All feedback was kind and constructive.

This course's pacing was very fast in the beginning, after mid term, things slowed down significantly. That is not to say that the class was easier, just that the pacing was much more relaxed after the Learn to Read Latin Book was completed. I felt that the pacing could have been slowed down to only leave about 4 weeks of translating passages so that the initial pacing of LATN 110 and 120 were not as extreme perspectively.
This course was excellent! CJ adapted the course very well to the exigencies of covid. He is a talented and skilled teacher, and I learned a great deal.
Overall good course, especially with Covid!
This class was well taught and concepts were covered thoroughly. The downside to this class is that it moves extremely fast.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt generally that the format that was provided was a good as it could have been given the circumstances. Personally, I would have liked it more if we were able to incorporate more of the actual lecture time in class, rather than merely reviewing the material together, but reading texts together at the end of the class was the true highlight of the course.
The mix of record lectures and in-person lessons worked very well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would strongly recommend this course, if it was taught by the same instructor. I've now been in his courses for a year, and they rank among the best language classes (and some of the best classes at Yale) I have ever taken. They are an excellent example of inclusive, rigorous language pedagogy from someone with a clear passion for teaching and the classics.

I would first warn them about the sheer time commitment that this class requires. There were many weeks were students were expected to study around 2-3hours each day to complete just the daily assigned work. But I would tell them that they would certainly learn Latin.
Yes, absolutely.
Yes! You will actually learn whether you want to or not, and it will be so worth it!
If you are interested in Latin and Roman history, yes!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: CJ also recorded lectures and gave us online resources. There was an optional virtual study day for the one day in which we did not meet synchronously, and a generous number of opportunities for one-on-one reading practice with the instructor.
Recorded lectures with In person review/reading sessions
This course included a combination of recorded lectures and virtual seminar/discussion sessions.
recorded grammar lessons
FIrst half of the class consisted of pre-recorded lecture videos on grammatical concepts
